Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Liquid/Supercritical Fluid Chromatoghraphy Mass Spectrometer for Energy and Environmental Research

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award from the Major Research Instrumentation Program will fund the acquisition of a liquid chromatography/supercritical fluid/mass spectrometer (LC/SFC/MS) for both environmental and energy research at Lafayette College and proximate universities. The LC/SFC/MS will enable the quantification and identification of components in these systems. The enhanced understanding of each system would allow for the development of strategies to mediate negative implications and optimize for beneficial outcomes related to energy and environmental applications. Additionally, the use of the LC/SFC/MS by neighboring institutions will further these goals and provide outreach opportunities for training in both the use of the instrument as well as green chemistry and engineering. The instrumentation will be used by multiple groups for research and provide educational experiences for undergraduate student researchers. When appropriate this instrumentation will also serve as an advanced teaching tool in multiple classes.

The LC/SFC/MS is a combined system that will transform the research capabilities at Lafayette College. The instrument is capable of high definition and accurate analyses with sufficient versatility for use in many applications. The unique combination of LC and SFC will make both reverse- and normal-phase separations accessible to our faculty and student researchers for a wide range of target analytes. MS coupled to a chromatography system is a robust technique possessing the ability to perform unknown molecule identification and compound isolation from complex matrices while providing ample sensitivity for quantification and identification of components with a wide spectrum of volatilities that range from polar to nonpolar. This instrumentation will be used to advance high impact faculty-led research relevant to energy and environmental applications with specific projects as follows: 1) CO2 mediated reactions for selective and sustainable biodiesel production, 2) Selective extraction and recycling of valuable co-products from microalgae using green solvents, 3) Product identification and mechanism elucidation of atmospheric aerosol growth pathways, and 4) Understanding of the production and fate of thiols in freshwater systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The liquid-chromatography/supercritical-fluid/mass spectrometer (LC/SFC/MS) acquired through this grant is a unique system that has provided the high powered analytical abilities and flexibility to enable significant results for a variety of research applications.  The instrument is used by faculty and undergraduate students across campus - in engineering and natural sciences - at Lafayette College.  Specifically, the applications have included environmental, energy, and biological systems and have  increased educational and training opportunities for students and faculty/staff alike.  Furthermore, the instrument is available to researchers across the Lehigh Valley; training was provided to interested parties and materials are generally available. 

The instrument provides high definition and accurate analyses with sufficient versatility to be used across many applications. The unique combination of LC and SFC allows for analytical separations necessary for environmental and energy research in a wide range of sample matrices. MS coupled to a chromatography system uniquely provides the ability to perform unknown molecule identification and compound isolation from complex matrices while providing ample sensitivity for quantification and identification of components.

The instrument has so far directly led to data for the publication of 4 peer-reviewed research articles as well as a large number of presentations at  national conferences.  Regrading aerosol pathways, the papers have developed methods for the use of this instrument for atmospheric systems and identified heterocyclic products of reactions occurring between small carbonyls and ammonium salts ubiquitous in atmospheric water systems that can be difficult to separate with traditional methods.  Currently, the instrument is being used to study reaction products in previously unidentified carbonyl reaction systems as well as photolysis products of complex compounds often found in atmospheric particles.  In the biofuel research, the instrument was used to quantify intermediate and reaction products in a novel fashion that significantly reduced the sample prep time and potential errors.  One on-going study has quantified bio-based monomers that have been extracted from biomass for renewable polymer production and will be used for a funded collaborative grant. The instrument is also being used to quantify products from green solvent extraction from various biomass sources.  Clearly, the instrument has and will be utilized for impactful research, training, and outreach as detailed in the Intellectual Merits and Broader Impacts sections below:

INTELLECTUAL MERITS: The LC/SFC/MS has transformed the research capabilities at Lafayette College, specifically for faculty-led research including: 1) CO2 mediated reactions for selective and sustainable biodiesel production, 2) Selective extraction and recycling of valuable co-products from biomass using green solvents, and 3) Product identification and mechanism elucidation of aerosol growth pathways.  So far, at least four other faculty at Lafayette have meaningfully used the instrument for their research. The instrument has allowed for research collaborations across campus and will provide analytical capabilities for years to come.

BROADER IMPACTS: The LC/SFC/MS was selected as a versatile and robust instrument that has expanded the research infrastructure at Lafayette College specifically in faculty-led research areas as well as within the science and engineering curriculum. Lafayette is committed to providing state-of-the-art research programs and experiential learning opportunities to undergraduate students. Faculty members are dedicated to undergraduate research mentoring and collaboration within and external to the College. Access to an LC/SFC/MS has created opportunities for undergraduates to grow as well rounded and well trained scientists with potential impactful discoveries that will be enabled by this instrumentation.

The results of this research have been communicated via peer-reviewed publications and scientific conferences for information dissemination and to develop student communication skills.  Students are co-authors on all publications and have presented the majority of the conference presentations.  Within the PIs' reesearch groups, 13 students have used the instrument, with 9 of the students being women. 

A workshop was developed and used as outreach to other Lehigh Valley institutions for the dissemination of green chemistry and engineering tools associated with it, particularly the SFC. In this workshop, the instrument was used to demonstrate the unique capabilities of the SFC and educate interested researchers and students on this technology.
